subject: Design
title: Hick's Law: Too Many Choices Paralyze
description: A quick win: understand Hick's Law: Too Many Choices Paralyze.

hook.text: A jam study gave shoppers 24 flavors or 6. The big display attracted crowds. The small one sold ten times more.

buildup.text: Hick's Law states that decision time increases logarithmically with the number of choices.

discovery.text: More options don't mean better UX. They mean slower, more anxious, less satisfied users.

twist.text: Netflix nearly killed its business with too many choices. Its algorithm exists to reduce your options.

climax.text: Every great UX design reduces choices to what matters ‚Äî filtering the world so users don't have to.

punchline.text: Less choice, faster action. Hick proved it in 1952.

quiz.question: What does Hick's Law describe?
options: Decision time increasing with more choices
